prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Deep Band 9 observations for the spectroscopically-confirmed galaxy at z=4.224, targeting its [OIII]88um line and simultaneously its dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As shown in Table 1 of Science Justification, the total far-infrared luminosity of this target is 5.9e+13 Lsun. According to the model calculations by Inoue et al. (2014), expected [OIII]88um fluxes from the galaxy are estimated to be 2.2e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 1, 3.0e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.2, and 4.9e-16 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.02. Assuming that the velocity width (FWHM) of the line is 100 km/s, the [OIII] line peak flux densities for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s are estimated to be 1.7e+2 mJy for Z/Zsun = 0.02 and higher values for the higher metallicities. The size of this galaxy in 870um continuum is about 4 times of the synthesized beam. In order to detect the [OIII]88um line peak with a high S/N, i.e., S/N=10 even in the case of Z/Zsun=0.02, we need to achieve a sensitivity per beam of 1.72e+2 / 10 / sqrt(4) = 8.6 mJy/beam for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s. From the total far-infrared luminosity, the 0.5 mm continuum flux density is estimated to be 22.3 mJy/beam, on the assumption of a modified blackbody SED with a dust temperature estimated by Gullberg et al. (2015) and an emissivity index of 2.0. Our Band 9 observations will also detect the 0.5 continuum with a high S/N that is sufficient for our science goal.

We choose a 1875.0 MHz bandwidth with a 7.813 MHz resolution and a spectral averaging of 16 for the [OIII] line (Baseband-1), and a 2000 MHz bandwidth with a 31.250 MHz resolution or the continuum (Baseband-2, 3, and 4), in the dual polarization mode. This will enable us to observe the [OIII] line and the 0.5 mm continuum simultaneously.

In order to observe the same spatial resolution as has been used in previous Band 7 program (Vieira et al. 2013), we choose a spatial resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This will make it easier to estimate the continuum flux density ratio between 0.9 mm (Band 7) and 0.5 mm (Band 9). In addition, it may allow us to investigate the physical properties of the interstellar medium in this source such as ionization parameter and gas density based on the [OIII]/[CII] line ratio map, making use of a gravitational lens modeling and photoionization model calculations. Note that the largest angular structure in this source is about 3.0 arcsec, and this observation does not need the ACA according to the OT suggestion.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Deep Band 9 observations for the spectroscopically-confirmed galaxy at z=4.232, targeting its [OIII]88um line and simultaneously its dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As shown in Table 1 of Science Justification, the total far-infrared luminosity of this target is 2.1e+13 Lsun. According to the model calculations by Inoue et al. (2014), expected [OIII]88um fluxes from the galaxy are estimated to be 7.8e-16 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 1, 1.0e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.2, and 1.7e-16 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.02. Assuming that the velocity width (FWHM) of the line is 100 km/s, the [OIII] line peak flux densities for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s are estimated to be 6.1e+1 mJy for Z/Zsun = 0.02 and higher values for the higher metallicities. The size of this galaxy in 870um continuum is about 4 times of the synthesized beam. In order to detect the [OIII]88um line peak with a high S/N, i.e., S/N=10 even in the case of Z/Zsun=0.02, we need to achieve a sensitivity per beam of 6.10e+1 / 10 / sqrt(4) = 3.1 mJy/beam for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s. From the total far-infrared luminosity, the 0.5 mm continuum flux density is estimated to be 15.2 mJy/beam, on the assumption of a modified blackbody SED with a dust temperature estimated by Gullberg et al. (2015) and an emissivity index of 2.0. Our Band 9 observations will also detect the 0.5 continuum with a high S/N that is sufficient for our science goal.

We choose a 1875.0 MHz bandwidth with a 7.813 MHz resolution and a spectral averaging of 16 for the [OIII] line (Baseband-1), and a 2000 MHz bandwidth with a 31.250 MHz resolution or the continuum (Baseband-2, 3, and 4), in the dual polarization mode. This will enable us to observe the [OIII] line and the 0.5 mm continuum simultaneously.

In order to observe the same spatial resolution as has been used in previous Band 7 program (Vieira et al. 2013), we choose a spatial resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This will make it easier to estimate the continuum flux density ratio between 0.9 mm (Band 7) and 0.5 mm (Band 9). In addition, it may allow us to investigate the physical properties of the interstellar medium in this source such as ionization parameter and gas density based on the [OIII]/[CII] line ratio map, making use of a gravitational lens modeling and photoionization model calculations. Note that the largest angular structure in this source is about 3.0 arcsec, and this observation does not need the ACA according to the OT suggestion.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Deep Band 9 observations for the spectroscopically-confirmed galaxy at z=4.281, targeting its [OIII]88um line and simultaneously its dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As shown in Table 1 of Science Justification, the total far-infrared luminosity of this target is 3.3e+13 Lsun. According to the model calculations by Inoue et al. (2014), expected [OIII]88um fluxes from the galaxy are estimated to be 1.2e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 1, 1.6e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.2, and 2.7e-16 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.02. Assuming that the velocity width (FWHM) of the line is 100 km/s, the [OIII] line peak flux densities for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s are estimated to be 9.4e+1 mJy for Z/Zsun = 0.02 and higher values for the higher metallicities. The size of this galaxy in 870um continuum is comparable to that of the synthesized beam. In order to detect the [OIII]88um line peak with a high S/N, i.e., S/N=10 even in the case of Z/Zsun=0.02, we need to achieve a sensitivity per beam of 9.43e+1 / 10 / sqrt(1) = 9.4 mJy/beam for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s. From the total far-infrared luminosity, the 0.5 mm continuum flux density is estimated to be 60.7 mJy/beam, on the assumption of a modified blackbody SED with a dust temperature estimated by Gullberg et al. (2015) and an emissivity index of 2.0. Our Band 9 observations will also detect the 0.5 continuum with a high S/N that is sufficient for our science goal.

We choose a 1875.0 MHz bandwidth with a 7.813 MHz resolution and a spectral averaging of 16 for the [OIII] line (Baseband-1), and a 2000 MHz bandwidth with a 31.250 MHz resolution or the continuum (Baseband-2, 3, and 4), in the dual polarization mode. This will enable us to observe the [OIII] line and the 0.5 mm continuum simultaneously.

In order to observe the same spatial resolution as has been used in previous Band 7 program (Vieira et al. 2013), we choose a spatial resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This will make it easier to estimate the continuum flux density ratio between 0.9 mm (Band 7) and 0.5 mm (Band 9). In addition, it may allow us to investigate the physical properties of the interstellar medium in this source such as ionization parameter and gas density based on the [OIII]/[CII] line ratio map, making use of a gravitational lens modeling and photoionization model calculations. Note that the largest angular structure in this source is about 0.5 arcsec, and this observation does not need the ACA according to the OT suggestion.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Deep Band 9 observations for the spectroscopically-confirmed galaxy at z=4.296, targeting its [OIII]88um line and simultaneously its dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As shown in Table 1 of Science Justification, the total far-infrared luminosity of this target is 9.2e+13 Lsun. According to the model calculations by Inoue et al. (2014), expected [OIII]88um fluxes from the galaxy are estimated to be 3.3e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 1, 4.4e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.2, and 7.3e-16 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.02. Assuming that the velocity width (FWHM) of the line is 100 km/s, the [OIII] line peak flux densities for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s are estimated to be 2.6e+2 mJy for Z/Zsun = 0.02 and higher values for the higher metallicities. The size of this galaxy in 870um continuum is comparable to that of the synthesized beam. In order to detect the [OIII]88um line peak with a high S/N, i.e., S/N=10 even in the case of Z/Zsun=0.02, we need to achieve a sensitivity per beam of 2.61e+2 / 10 / sqrt(1) = 2.6e+1 mJy/beam for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s. From the total far-infrared luminosity, the 0.5 mm continuum flux density is estimated to be 106 mJy/beam, on the assumption of a modified blackbody SED with a dust temperature estimated by Gullberg et al. (2015) and an emissivity index of 2.0. Our Band 9 observations will also detect the 0.5 continuum with a high S/N that is sufficient for our science goal.

We choose a 1875.0 MHz bandwidth with a 7.813 MHz resolution and a spectral averaging of 16 for the [OIII] line (Baseband-1), and a 2000 MHz bandwidth with a 31.250 MHz resolution or the continuum (Baseband-2, 3, and 4), in the dual polarization mode. This will enable us to observe the [OIII] line and the 0.5 mm continuum simultaneously.

In order to observe the same spatial resolution as has been used in previous Band 7 program (Vieira et al. 2013), we choose a spatial resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This will make it easier to estimate the continuum flux density ratio between 0.9 mm (Band 7) and 0.5 mm (Band 9). In addition, it may allow us to investigate the physical properties of the interstellar medium in this source such as ionization parameter and gas density based on the [OIII]/[CII] line ratio map, making use of a gravitational lens modeling and photoionization model calculations. Note that the largest angular structure in this source is about 1.0 arcsec, and this observation does not need the ACA according to the OT suggestion.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Deep Band 9 observations for the spectroscopically-confirmed galaxy at z=4.567, targeting its [OIII]88um line and simultaneously its dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As shown in Table 1 of Science Justification, the total far-infrared luminosity of this target is 2.7e+13 Lsun. According to the model calculations by Inoue et al. (2014), expected [OIII]88um fluxes from the galaxy are estimated to be 8.3e-16 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 1, 1.1e-15 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.2, and 1.9e-16 erg/s/cm2 for Z/Zsun = 0.02. Assuming that the velocity width (FWHM) of the line is 100 km/s, the [OIII] line peak flux densities for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s are estimated to be 7.0e+1 mJy for Z/Zsun = 0.02 and higher values for the higher metallicities. The size of this galaxy in 870um continuum is about 2 times of the synthesized beam. In order to detect the [OIII]88um line peak with a high S/N, i.e., S/N=10 even in the case of Z/Zsun=0.02, we need to achieve a sensitivity per beam of 6.98e+1 / 10 / sqrt(2) = 4.9 mJy/beam for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s. From the total far-infrared luminosity, the 0.5 mm continuum flux density is estimated to be 27.0 mJy/beam, on the assumption of a modified blackbody SED with a dust temperature estimated by Gullberg et al. (2015) and an emissivity index of 2.0. Our Band 9 observations will also detect the 0.5 continuum with a high S/N that is sufficient for our science goal.

We choose a 1875.0 MHz bandwidth with a 7.813 MHz resolution and a spectral averaging of 16 for the [OIII] line (Baseband-1), and a 2000 MHz bandwidth with a 31.250 MHz resolution or the continuum (Baseband-2, 3, and 4), in the dual polarization mode. This will enable us to observe the [OIII] line and the 0.5 mm continuum simultaneously.

In order to observe the same spatial resolution as has been used in previous Band 7 program (Vieira et al. 2013), we choose a spatial resolution of 0.5 arcsec. This will make it easier to estimate the continuum flux density ratio between 0.9 mm (Band 7) and 0.5 mm (Band 9). In addition, it may allow us to investigate the physical properties of the interstellar medium in this source such as ionization parameter and gas density based on the [OIII]/[CII] line ratio map, making use of a gravitational lens modeling and photoionization model calculations. Note that the largest angular structure in this source is about 3.0 arcsec, and this observation does not need the ACA according to the OT suggestion.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose Band 9 observations for 5 spectroscopically-confirmed submillimeter galaxies at z = 4.224-4.567. We target an [Oiii]88um line that is one of the strongest far-infrared lines from Hii regions and a good indicator of oxygen abundance. This program will complement previous ALMA observations for high-redshift galaxies, targeting a [Cii]158um line from photodissociation regions that poorly determines metallicity. Our goals are to detect [Oiii]88um of our targets, and estimate oxygen abundance at the highest redshift ever obtained. Since it is difficult to achieve a high enough sensitivity to detect [Oiii]88um emission from high-redshift galaxies with previous instruments, observational studies on [Oiii]88um have been limited to sources at z < 4. Due to the atmospheric transmission, high-sensitivity [Oiii]88um observations are still limited to redshift ranges of z ~= 3.76-4.15, 4.19-4.42, and 4.51-4.63 for ALMA Band 9. This challenging experiment is enabled by our targets, which are identified by a combination of SPT and ALMA surveys.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for Cosmic Ray Research, The University of Tokyo
